description.text:
Spacer that goes in between the cogs for a 10 speed Shimano cassette. Your mileage may vary with SRAM/Campagnolo cassettes - see the design section.

https://www.amazon.com/Shimano-HG-Gear-Cassette-Spacer-2-56-mm/dp/B001GSKSNY/ref=sr_1_15?s=sporting-goods&ie=UTF8&qid=1485449785&sr=1-15&keywords=cassette+spacer They cost too much.

Pretty sure it'll be strong enough. I'll let you know if I have problems.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

I used the default layer height. Printed a second batch with 0.1 mm layer height; haven't checked it yet.

Of the nine I printed, I got:

2.2x mm: 1
2.3x mm: 5
2.4x mm: 4

with the default layer height.

Double check before you mount because those little 0.0x mm measurements add up, especially if you have no riveted sections (complete custom cogs). Check Sheldon Brown's cribsheet to see just how close they are between 8/9/10/11 speed.

http://www.sheldonbrown.com/cribsheet-spacing.html I used Sheldon Brown's cribsheet to get the thickness right.

I referenced my 7 speed cassette on 8/9/10 freehub 4.5 mm spacer for the OD & ID.

Note that there are no notches in this piece that fit over the splines of the freehub body. I never understood why spacers needed these, & it just made the installation more tedious.

The splines in the cogs already prevent rotation relative to the freehub, so it seems redundant that the spacers themselves, which literally only provide spacing along the freehub axis, should have splines too.
28 Jan 17: Did a test print; it was a pretty tight fit for some of the spacers. A little filing would go a long way.

Supports:

No

title: Anet A8 fillament spool on top holder

description.text:
I wanted to put the spool on top of the Anet A8 3d printer, but couldn't find one up to my requirements and decided to make a new one. The requirements are it to be:

  • stable
  • easy to mount, not requiring anything to be disassembled
  • somehow flexible (to accommodate some differences in rod lengths)
  • potentially upgradeable
  • to provide mounting holes (pockets) for additions
  • easily printable
  • to be immediately usable after it is printed.

There were some holders, which were close to what I wanted, the best matches being
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1505075 by DeAtHfOrToLd, its remix http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1743397 by dldesign and some similar things, but all of those required to unmount the display plate to fix them. I wanted the item just to "click" on its place, and not to dismount anything. So, I designed this holder.

Mounting:

The mounting is quite simple and fast.

The thing consists of 3 main parts plus two (optional) small disks to limit the axial (left-right) movement of the spool rod.
The 3 main parts have to be assembled together, by plugging the Left and Right hook into the trapezoid pockets of the holder. The pockets are different size, so the right hook would not fit in the left pocket and the left hook will be very loose if fitted in the right pocket. Still pay attention to fit the hooks in their respective place, also considering the orientation. The hooks fit tightly in the pockets so you need to apply some force to fully fit them (I applied some soft hammering for example). This is done intentionally to assure firm connection between the hooks and the frame.

After you have the hooks firmly attached to the frame carefully mount it on top of the printer, pushing slowly down until the hooks "click" on their place. After the frame is fully inserted you may need to push a bit the bottom of the hooks towards the bottom bolts until they lock on them.

After that you will have the holder firmly attached to the printer.

if you want print and insert the small disks in the pockets on the top of the holder to limit the movement of the spool rod.

The square holes on the bottom side can be used to design and mount attachments like filament guides i.e.

Hope you will like it.

Note: The distance from the rod to the bottom of the holder is 115mm, which requires the spool to be centered to the rod. Just print some spool centering cones like these ones http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:763812 by BJoe, but there are many others available too.

The FreeCad file is attached for anyone who wants to further improve the design or make some additions. It may be adapted to other Prusa clones as well. Just do not forget to mention the author ;-).

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Just print it, nothing special.

title: Z brace LED strip holder for Wanhao I3/Maker Select/Select Plus
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Edit: added 2 versions with tighter radius to clamp tighter on the threaded rod, the original printed fine for me on 4 of my printers, but if you have slipping issues on the treaded rod, check those out and let me know in the comments if you need a tighter version.

Azza's z braces http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:921948 are in the perfect spot for a front LED light, however there were no designs to add them. So I designed these, which clip on to 5/16 threaded rod. Use 3 for each side, and add LED strip covers: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2064682. These re printed in PLA, they can turn somewhat with pressure to adjust but do not require any glue or zip ties or anything to attach. I used a single zip tie on the bottom to hold the LED strip wiring.

My first design. See also my remix of LED strip holder to add LED strip to the gantry: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2064648

Full build:
Wire (This is what I had, 20 or 22ga are more than adequate): https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01CMHY892/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1
Sleeve:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B004UHJCFI/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1
Connectors: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01AHJMR4A/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1
24v to 12v converter: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01M24M2PR/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1
12v LED strip: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00HSF65MC/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1
Also needed: Heat shrink, soldering iron, 2 zip ties, adhesive pad to attach converter to machine

You need to have some comfort with soldering as the LED strips are all custom lengths.

Printable parts:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2064836 qty 6- PLA is fine, whatever color you want, these are orange in the picture, you want an opaque color
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2064648, 3 pairs of the 100mm, 1 pair of 50mm, 1 pair of 75mm, PLA is fine, you want an opaque color
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2064682, 10 x100mm, 2x50mm, 2x80mm and 1x horizontal- this is a special size. I printed these out of clear PETG as I had issues with the strength of the $8 el cheap natural PLA

The voltage converter fits in front of the power supply at the front of the machine, once it's stuck down you can figure out your wire lengths. I joined the wires for the gantry and right Z brace light to one wire and left to a second, using quick connects and sleeving for everything to keep things neat. All connections must be hot soldered and shrink tubed.

To assemble the printed pieces:

Gantry sides: 2x100mm led holder and 1x50mm led holder. Gantry horizontal: 2x100mm, 1x75mm led holder. LED strip from right side all the way across and down to left, making sure that you get the strip all the way into the corner and make a sharp angle or the covers won't fit. Then attach the LED covers, 2x100mm and 1x80mm on the vertical sides, 2x100mm and 1x horizontal for the horizontal side, it should be a tight fit.

Z braces: 3x100mm LED clip for each side, 2x100mm and 1x50mm led cover for each side, with a zip tie on the bottom of each to help prevent wire tug.

Printer:

MP Select Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

60%

Notes:

3 shells, 4 bottom layers, 4 top layers. Print flat to minimize z banding and wobble.

Original idea from Raul Krauthausen, for more info, please check his website : http://raul.de/inspiring/printing-a-mini-wheelchair-ramp-yourself-with-a-3d-printer/

We decided to push the concept with a dovetail groove so the ramp can reach higher sidewalks once you put the second part. Also, do not forget to print the little feet in a flexible material in order to get a nice grip on the floor.

This is a simple inverse magnetic "pendulum", it uses powerful embedded magnet to create the effect of a levitating object. Use a thin nylon chord, fishing line, etc to attach the weight metal part and insert it in the lower hole, fix it it with a M3 screw o something. The powerful 30x10 NIB magnet inside the upper part will create a magnetic field strong enough to keep floating in the air small ferromagnetic metal objects, just fix the fishing line at an apropiate distance. The effect of a pendulum that keep its position even inverted is awesome!!

At print time: You will need a software/printer that can pause print at a custom height to be able to insert the magnet in the pendulum at mid print, and also to insert a 12mm steel ball in the weight cube. Dont use support for print. Remember you can even use a ball from some old Newton craddle you have around, these steel balls already have a hole for the fishing line. You can also use any other metal piece to make it levitate. Pics shows a part using a 20mm stainless steel ball harvested from an oldie Newton's cradle. If you don't have a 30x10mm magnet you can use any other size and adapt it to the room using plasticine or an adapter or something, or just edit the included CAD sources, it is a very simple design.

Keep your visitors amazed !!
Enjoy!

UPDATE (30-MAR-2017): Added a model for a 10x10x5 mm magnet weight. You'll have to pause print to insert the magnet, In case you have a ferromagnetic nozzle stick it with a drop of glue and continue printing. This magnet loaded weight allows for an increased distance from the main magnet making the levitating effect even more awesome.

comments.text: These magnets worked perfect and are very cheap. Just snap the two 5mm magnets together and viola you have a 10mm magnet!

3 .Making Photographs with the P66
?You don't take a photograph, you make it -attributed to Ansel Adams
If you've never used a film camera, if you've only used a smartphone or a digital point-and-shoot, welcome to real photography. Making pinhole photographs engages a necessary emotional and temporal involvement. With a pinhole camera and its tiny aperture, this creative act is slowed down, time is exploded, space is warped. There is no undo, no delete. After your negatives are finally processed, printed or scanned, you will remember your relationship with your photographic subjects. You will mourn failed shots, and your successes will lift you with pride and profound joy. Truly.

description.text:
The Crashex v2 is a FPV racer with a motor-to-motor distance of 21,5 cm. The camera angle is fixed, but I am planning to design a wedge that can be inserted if a bigger/smaller angle is desired. This is a proven design that flies nice and stable with a CC3D flight controller, M2204-2300kV motors from Ldpower and 6030 props. The arms are designed to protect the motor cables and there is plenty of room for all components. With a 2200 mAh battery I achieve flight times between 10 and 13 Minutes.

V3 will probably be done within the next 6 months. The plan is to achieve an even lower weight without losing its robustness and to fly it with 3-blade props and shorter arms. The distance between the upper floor and the second floor is a little too short in v2, so that some cables keep the battery from lying flat on the upper floor. That has been no problem so far, but is not very nice and will be addressed in v3.

eZ430-Chronos comes with 2 usb devices. One is TI eZ430U simulator that is basically ICSP + debugger and is used to program & debug the mcu in chronos and the other device is BlueRobin transceiver. Both are very small and look fragile and they both come \"naked\" hence I decided to box them. This is the case for the eZ430U debugger/programmer/simulator. (The case for BlueRobin is here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2057 )

See http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2064758
Christmas ball plane

I strongly think that 3D printing is only part of the fun! Assembled objects are awesome and I really like mixing materials and elements like bolts, nuts and aluminum...this is my design for a Solder Spool Stand, the extra parts you need are a few inches of 3/4" aluminum tube (could be replaced by a PVC pipe), aluminum for the handle, some M3 bolts, some foam (used as anti-slip surface for the base...could also be replaced by four rubber feet) and, the most important, -and extremely useful for 3D printings!- some M3 thread inserts (link attached below).

There is only one file for the side of the holder but, being both sides similar, you just have to print it twice.

http://www.ebay.com/itm/M1-4-M1-6-M2-M2-5-M3-Brass-Insert-Threaded-Decorative-Embedded-Knurled-Nuts/142002147708?_trksid=p2047675.c100623.m-1&_trkparms=aid%3D222007%26algo%3DSIC.MBE%26ao%3D1%26asc%3D20160323102634%26meid%3Dc03d421e4c6f414599f08b3f18eb8f2f%26pid%3D100623%26rk%3D3%26rkt%3D6%26sd%3D351490410356

Please comment and share if you make it.

Cheers!

UPDATED: 04/03/2017: The handle used to be placed below the C.G. (Center of Gravity) so, the holder tend to flip down when I grab it. I modified the design to add a hole for the thread-insert right at the center of the solder spool what solves the problem and at the same time prevents the solder spool from falling off the stand. The remaining hole at the center of the piece could be used as a second bolt thread-insert if you want to have a fixed non-basculating handle...The only limitation now is that you can't replace the aluminum tube for a wood dowel...but you still can use a PVC pipe!

UPDATED: 05/03/2017: A handle was added!

description.text:
Check out our Etsy for all of our 3D printed awesomeness!
https://www.etsy.com/shop/3DCentral

Bearings we use: Amazon, $7.84 for 8

Buy this spinner fully assembled from our Etsy: Click here!

A cool sideways twist on the standard Tri-Spinner design! This tri-spinner holds the three bearings on the side at a 90 degree angle, so they actually roll across your fingers when you spin it! Print it out and give it a shot!

To assemble, push the spinners into the slots on the side and use the tubes to hold them in place. After all three are inserted, push the final bearing in, and use a little bit of CA glue to hold it in place.

You can find our Youtube video on the standard Tri-Spinner here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GB4WBj8TMDg

Check out our YouTube channel for build videos and other cool stuff!

https://www.youtube.com/c/3dcentralva

title: Anet A6 extended x-axis limit switch bracket for use with inductive sensor

description.text:
I had an issue with the x-axis limit switch on my Anet A6 not triggering after installing an inductive sensor probe. I used the holder from: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1785616. Therefore I made this extended mounting bracket for the limit switch, so it triggers before the sensor hits. The bracket is 6mm longer than usual, which in my case was just enough to stop the probe from hitting first instead of the limit switch.

If you need a longer version, download FreeCad and use the source file to modify this thing.

comments.text: I'm going to use this on my standard A6... The standard part holds the switch too close to the extruder and it never depresses... The X carriage hits the left hand Z frame and I can hear the motor straining badly.

title: Orbiter Nexus 5X Case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Designed another phone-case (given that its been 4 years since the last one), can you tell I like spaceships!?

Anyways, feel free to download and make your own, and check out the sketches and process of design below.

Disclaimer: The printed parts in the cover picture were professionally printed and ordered through Shapeways, using the stronge and flexible plastic option. The details in the prints were too much for my little home-made printer

Initial design sketches, right is the original sketch from 2015 for Samsung Galaxy S4 phone, left is the adapted design to fit my newer Nexus 5X Initial Design and Sketches

I originally designed the case in my engineering notebook with a few sketches of how it would look. I used the following image for reference: https://www.howitworksdaily.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/6938210-space-shuttle-photos.jpg

After being unsuccessful at locating a usable and accurate CAD model of the Nexus 5X I took to my phone with a pair of calipers and made a really basic stand in with which the case models would be built around and tested.

Following that I created two cases which would interface with each other, one fitting over the phone, then another fitting over the first case. From there I layed out how I wanted portions of the design to align through the various levels. Knowing my phone was black I wanted to be able to use it in combination with orange and white.

Once the case designs were complete I took to sketching out the design and making cuts where they needed to align.

I worked primarily in assembly mode in Solidworks where I could edit the part based on how it would look with the phone and additional case, which made visualizing much easier.

Once all was done design-wise I uploaded it to Shapeways, and continued to make various tweaks based on wall-thickness, and a few fillets of concern before it was ready to be ordered.

Transferring the general sketch to the inner case The final put together assembly in Solidworks before uploading stl files and ordering printed versions

description.text:
A spool holder that hangs on the side of the Flashforge Finder 3D printer.

PLEASE READ ALL INSTRUCTIONS

You will need to print out the Spool Hook as well as the Guide Tube Holder then you have the choice of two different sizes of the Spool Roll rod.

If you have any questions on assembly or improvements please let me know.

Note: The Flashforge Finder branded filaments will fit on this spool holder but you will have to take the spool rod out first because the spool wont fit over the lip on the end.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

FlashForge Finder

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Notes:

All pieces can be oriented to fit on the Flashforge Finder build area and can be printed without support.

After parts are printed:

I suggest gluing the Filament Guide Holder onto the Spool Hook so that they are a rigid part which helps prevent tangles. I suggest you leave the Spool Rod unglued so if the spool of filament you are using doesn't fit over the end you can pull the rod off and put it on that way.

I needed to put a micro-usb female connector in a case where there was a cutout for a standard db9 serial connector. So I made this simple adapter.
It allows for soldering in place, room for wires or pinheader.

The small lock keeps the board in place quite nicely but do break easily when removed.
It was made to just press in and lock.. If it's to loose just widen the "legs" a bit..

There is a model of the board included, I've made a margin of around .2mm to allow for slightly variation in sizes... The pcb was measured with a digital caliber..

Easy to modify if you have another board or different case..
Original sketchup 2017 file included..

author: vvadda

title: Dungeon Dolls: Star Wizard
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Updated 2/19/17

Ever like the variable designs of FlatMinis, but the customization of Dungeon Dolls? Ever wanted more options? Look no further! Inspired by the aesthetic of GrumpyRobot's FlatMinis, and DutchMogul's Dungeon Doll system, come Trixster_98's take on the classic Dungeon Doll.

This handy stereotypical Star Wizard includes two staff's with differing handle placement, star covered pants, star dazzled shirt, a stereotypical pointy star hat, and a plain base. I printed mine at 200% (Red) and the base stands at 56 mm tall. You can also print at 150% (Grey) which stands at 42 mm. Fully customizable and modular, look for more designs to come in the following weeks.

These designs are fully compatible with DutchMogul's original Dungeon Dolls, but not with FlatMinis
Made in Tinkercad, red printed at my library, grey printed on my Monoprice MP Select Mini
The remixed and improved version of my 2014 work that was unprintable and abandoned shortly after inception

Printing
The pieces should be printed at 150-200% depending on what you feel your printers accuracy to be. My printer can make all the details clearly visible at 100% but needs the print to be at 150% in order to fit together well.
The picture shows the 3 sizes of 200%, 150%, and 100%

Preparation
In order for the pieces to properly fit together, you will need to lightly sand them with a set of needle files. The heads just need very minute sanding in the eye holes. My first layer is always slightly off which always needs work in that one spot. The studs that attach to the shirt and pants need light sanding, but the holes should be fine, depending on your printers accuracy. The shirt stud typically needs a very small amount of sanding compared to the pant studs. The bottom that fits onto the base will most likely need sanding on both the hole and stud depending on accuracy.

Always test fit pieces together as you sand. I'm not responsible for ruined pieces due to too much sanding.

description.text:
I wanted to produce a fin that maintained the general appearance of the stock Blade 180CFX tail fin, but in the color of my choosing. I drew it up, printed it out and it fits, so I'm happy.

I printed it on a glass bed, 210C / 55C, and I use 3 skirt lines to make sure I have a good squish all the way around.

Make sure the fin is flipped so the locating pin on the back side of the fin is facing upward when printing.

Support to mount a 12mm inductive sensor, screws from the extruder carriage are two short to be used with the mount so you will need a longer m3 screw, I have it mounted with only one long screw and a short one from the carriage and it fits nice.

I wanted to create a cable chain system for the M2 that does not require rewiring or modifications to the frame. This system has 2 piece links that allow the chain to be applied over the existing cable shielding. The chain ends mount with existing holes. The head end replaces the existing cap that holds down the cables and is held in place by 3 small zip ties. The frame end will need to be held in place by a 3/4 inch bolt and nut and utilizes an existing hole in the frame. It took 22 links to fully cover my existing wiring but that may change from printer to printer.

title: Thermal Detonator
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a Thermal Detonator, consisting of four parts. The top and bottom halves of the sphere, a sliding button that goes on top and a small cap that will cover an LED in the top half of the sphere.
The files has four holes that can accommodate three 3mm LEDs and one 1,8mm LED.
The sliding button clips into place in the slot in the top half of the sphere and can be used to attach and activate a button for electronics that can be housed inside.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GELZkQZjxAA

description.header: Arduino Code for the blinking LEDs
description.text:
int led1 = 5; //Specify to which pin you are connecting the Left Oragne LED
int led2 = 7; //Specify to which pin you are connecting the Middle Oragne LED
int led3 = 9; //Specify to which pin you are connecting the Right Oragne LED
int led4 = 11; //Specify to which pin you are connecting the Red LED

// the setup routine runs once when you press reset:
void setup() {
// initialize the digital pin as an output.
pinMode(led1, OUTPUT);
pinMode(led2, OUTPUT);
pinMode(led3, OUTPUT);
pinMode(led4, OUTPUT);
}

// the loop routine runs over and over again forever:
void loop() {

//Light Status 1
digitalWrite(led4, HIGH); //turn the red LED on

digitalWrite(led1, HIGH); // turn the Left Orange LED on
delay(600); // wait for 600 milliseconds

digitalWrite(led1, LOW); // turn the Left Orange LED on off
delay(600); // wait for 600 milliseconds

//Light Status 2
{digitalWrite(led2, HIGH);
delay(600);

digitalWrite(led2, LOW);
delay(600);}

//Light Status 3
{digitalWrite(led3, HIGH);
delay(600);

digitalWrite(led3, LOW);
delay(600);}

//Light Status 4
{digitalWrite(led1, HIGH);
digitalWrite(led2, HIGH);
delay(600);

digitalWrite(led1, LOW);
digitalWrite(led2, LOW);
delay(600);}

//Light Status 5
{digitalWrite(led1, HIGH);
digitalWrite(led3, HIGH);
delay(600);

digitalWrite(led1, LOW);
digitalWrite(led3, LOW);
delay(600);}

//Light Status 6
{digitalWrite(led3, HIGH);
delay(600);

digitalWrite(led3, LOW);
delay(600);}

//Light Status 7
{digitalWrite(led1, HIGH);
delay(600);

digitalWrite(led1, LOW);
delay(600);}

//Light Status 8
{digitalWrite(led2, HIGH);
digitalWrite(led3, HIGH);
delay(600);

digitalWrite(led2, LOW);
digitalWrite(led3, LOW);
delay(600);}

//Light Status 9
{digitalWrite(led1, HIGH);
digitalWrite(led3, HIGH);
delay(600);

digitalWrite(led1, LOW);
digitalWrite(led3, LOW);
delay(600);}

}

comments.text:
Hi, what kind of switch is used in that awesome Build?
All the other parts are ordered
comments.author: Karondkar

comments.text:
There is one of those standard breadboard switches in there now (https://i1.wp.com/volthauslab.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/09/btns.jpg). With a rubberish button top so it has a little bit of wiggle room. But the switch hast to be pushed all the way back and stay there for it to work.
On further reflecting I think it might be best to put a small spring and metal plate in there, like those in battery holders.
Spring on the housing, plate on the sliding switch, when they touch you complete the circuit. no switch required. That might give it a lot more leeway, is easier to stick into place and is very simple to set up.

description.text:
A 3D printable puzzle box, requires 5 actions to open, and is built from 10 parts.

It is created based on a wooden version, using the same parts as the original (unknown origin, claims to be from 1772). Some of the original parts were missing or damaged, but I think my model has come close to the original. The "Fix pin" and "Fix plate" were part of a later repair (1950s maybe) due to the box cracking.

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator 4x

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

10%

Notes:

Some pieces needs to be rotated for good print.

I have only test printed it at 60% size due to limited print area. Tolerances between the moving parts are about right, but might work better at full size.

The printed pins are easy to break, and hard to get correct size, if a sturdier box is desired replace them with a M4 (60%) or M8 (100%) -bolt depending on print size.
This is a nurbs model of a 5mm led made for Rhinoceros. I use it as a tool for make led holes in my models by boolean operations.

CL 260 Ultimaker UpGrades

Upgrade Teile für den CL 260 und ähnliche Drucker
Die Seite ist im Aufbau u. kann noch verändert werden.
für Anregungen oder Beiträge bin ich dankbar.

JETZT NEU! kompakter u- leichter Druckkopf für 11mm, 12mm und 15mm- Gleitlager, mit nur einem Filamentkühler, sehr leichte u. kompakte Bauweise mit soliden Befestigungsmöglichkeiten mittels 3M Schrauben u. Muttern u. oben zusätzliche Befestigungsmöglichkeiten beispielsweise für LED- Beleuchtung oder andere Filamentzuführung. Der Filamentkühler kommt mit einem Fan aus was die zu bewegende Masse minimiert und schnellere Druckgeschwindigkeit ermögllicht:

Bei den Riemenspanner für 11mm Lager ist ein "Halbring" dabei, (damit man den Druckkopf mitsamt den beiden Wellen einfach mal nach oben rausheben kann) und um das diesen kommen noch kleine Kabelbinder rum, damit ist alles stramm festgezurrt und es wackelt nichts. Durch die gebogene Riemenführung beim verstellbaren Teil bleiben die Abmessungen gering und es geht kein Bauraum verloren.

Für den Bau braucht man einige 3M Schauben und Muttern unterschiedlicher Längen

Druckerhaube:
Die Maße für die Acrylglasplatten 2mm der Zeichnung entnehmen´.
für Größenänderung müssen die Leisten "170131_Haube02-P1-a bis -g" nur in der Länge entsprechend skaliert werden.
Das 2mm Acrylglas hab ich beidseitig mit dem Tapetenmesser tief eingeritzt, dann läßt sich das sauber brechen.
Ich verwende es auch als abnehmbare Seitenwände, befestigt mit den Hammerschrauben (siehe oben).
Es gibt davon Platten mit z. B. 100 X 50 cm, somit braucht man nur jeweils die Breite abschneiden. Das ganze eignet sich gut zum ABS- Drucken, weil durch das "Gehäuse" die für ABS- Druck nötige Umgebungstemperatur von ca. 55° gegeben ist, so daß keine Verwerfungen entstehen.

Mehr Informationen gibt es hier:
https://www.facebook.com/groups/829299173846060/
http://www.thingiverse.com/joecool92/collections/cl260
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1800495

Neu! Teile für direkt extruder von flexibler Welle angetrieben (kompatibel mit compact head 11mm):
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2691910

CL 260 Ultimaker UpGrades

Upgrade parts for the CL 260 and similar printers
The page is under construction and can still be changed.
For suggestions or contributions I am grateful.

NOW NEW! Compact and light print head for 11mm, 12mm and 15mm slide bearings, with only one filament cooler, very light and compact design with solid mounting possibilities by means of 3M screws and nuts and above additional mounting possibilities for example for LED lighting or other filament feeding. The filament cooler comes with a fan which minimizes the mass to be moved and enables faster printing speed:

With the belt tensioner for 11mm bearing is a "Halbring" thereby, (so that the print head with the two shafts can simply rausmorgen) and around this come still small cable ties, so everything is tightly tied and it wobbles nothing. Due to the curved belt guide with the adjustable part, the dimensions remain small and no space is lost.

For the construction you need some 3M screws and nuts of different lengths

Printer hood:
Measure the dimensions for the acrylic glass plates 2mm from the drawing.
For size change, the strips "170131_Haube02-P1-a to -g" have to be scaled only in length.
The 2mm acrylic glass I have on both sides with the wallpaper knife deeply carved, then the clean can break.
I also use it as removable side walls, fixed with the hammer screws (see above).
There are plates with, for example, 100 x 50 cm, so you only need to cut the width. The whole is well suited for ABS printing because the ambient temperature of approx. 55 ° required for ABS pressure is provided by the "housing" so that no warping occurs.

title: Prusa i3 MK2 Upgrade kit for E3D Titan Extruder by S±E

description.text:
Remark 09.01.2018
Use a heat sock for the heater block to avoid thermal runaway when using a fan (https://e3d-online.com/v6-socks-pro-pack-of-3)
Update 11.05.2017
updated the assembly instruction
Update 25.04.2017
Extruder mount v1.1 with slightly enlarged hole for beeing able to adjust gear play
All parts in STEP (.stp) format provided in download section (downlaod as .rar)
Update 12.03.2017
fan mount V1.2 - Increased air flow throughput
fan mount V1.2x - for bigger fan GB1205PKV1-8AY

Enjoy the advantages of E3D Titan geared extruder with your Prusa i3 MK2

  • Increase force on filament by factor 3 to brute force every material without clogging
  • Print with tiny 0.15mm nozzle for outstanding detail quality
  • For more see http://e3d-online.com/Titan-Extruder

Download - Print - Assemble - Update Firmware (optional) - Print better!

We love to see this thing getting a lot of interest! Thanks, we have fun :)
Feel free to place further comments, ideas and proposals for improvement.
This version is installed on our Prusa i3 MK2. It fits and works absolutely flawless.

You'll need:

  • Prusa i3 MK2
  • E3D Titan Geared Extruder
  • THIS
  • cable ties, M3 nuts and hex-socket screws M3x40, x20, x16, x12
  • 1-2 beers (optional)

Optional nozzle fan mount for axial fan 40x40mm for better visibility of nozzle included.

Find attached:

  • STL files
  • brief assembly instruction
  • G-codes (ABS h0.25) - radial fan mount V1.0. Newer v1.2 not included
  • Firmware

Contact
[email protected]

BTC donations accepted
1Q5BGKPuR6X8ukKLjqMniW3nbSwm14uQaf

ETH donations accepted
0x8262f4CC4372473eb7B1bF686403152E83D15347

Concept
  • Easiest / most direct way to upgrade to E3D Titan
  • As few modifications as necessary
    • Firmware
    • Usage of original
      • E3D v6 nozzle + silicone sock
      • E-motor
      • PINDA sensor
      • Hotend fan
      • Nozzle fan
      • Bearings / bearings fixation (cable ties)
      • Belt fixation
    • Usage of standard parts
      • E3D cooling fan shroud (the blue injection molded)
        • Can also be printed (it’s included)
        • Metric screws and nuts M3
    • Keep original positions X Y Z
      • Nozzle
      • PINDA sensor
    • As less restriction of x-axis travelling distance as possible : 240mm instead of 250mm
      • More possible when omitting filament tightening knob and using allen key screw instead
  • Printability
    • All parts printable with Prusa i3 mk2
    • No support material required
    • All parts with 1 print (fill build plate)
    • As less material as necessary
  • Easy assembly
    • Fast change of hotend/nozzle
    • As few fixation points as necessary
    • proper cable management
  • Quality
    • Robust design
  • Flexibility
    • Usage of axial nozzle fan possible

Materials ABS:
I am using standard ABS in prusa orange to fit the original design nicely.
Depending on your print settings, you might encounter problems with bed adhesion for the x-carriage and the extruder mount, as ABS is known to be problematic in this regard for larger parts. It really depends on your experience and skill level to handle ABS.
Especially when printing the whole set in one print, the fact that it takes more time and therefore more difference in temperature for every next layer to printed on the one before leads to increasing the problem for the lager parts.
Hence, I recommend to print the x-carriage and the extruder mount seperately in single prints, when using ABS. The G-codes included are for ABS! Nozzle 0.4, layer height 0.25mm.

Current available versions

Extruder mount - V1.0
X-carriage - V1.0

Radial fan mount - V1.1 (improved printability)
Radial fan mount - V1.2 Increased air flow throughput
Radial fan mount - V1.2x for bigger fan GB1205PKV1-8AY
Axial fan mount - V1.0
Tightening knob - V1.0
Indicator - V1.0

All downloads will be updated to the newest versions.

Firmware

please check comment section as some encountered issues with the provided firmware <<

Thanks devilhunter84 for pointing out (comment section):
"You also don't need to change a thing in the firmware, you can use Prusa's Stock firmware (yay for updates)
Just do these little workarounds instead of using a custom firmware:
• reverse the polarity of the stepper motor, meaning plug it into the mini Rambo in reverse. This causes the extruder to go into the right direction.
use the gcode in your Slic3r settings
M907 X640 Z830 E800 ; set Titan Extruder Current
to give the Titan stepper more juice. the extruder with that big wheel now consumes more mAh, so give it a couple of mAh's more to avoid skipped steps. (just don't do silent/high power from the menu anymore or the extruder will skip again)
M92 X100.00 Y100.00 Z400.00 E837 ; set Titan E steps
this will use the correct stepping if you also got the 0.9 degree motor like me with the Titan. (for 1.8 stepping use your 418.5)"

Firmware update:
Use exact Arduino version 1.6.10 to update firmware!
Direct download link:
https://www.arduino.cc/download_handler.php?f=/arduino-1.6.10-windows.zip
Firmware modifications based on Version 3.0.9:

  • Steps per unit extruder 161.3 --> 418.5 (gear ratio)
  • Direction of extruder : INVERT_E0_DIR true --> INVERT_E0_DIR false (gear)
  • Unload filament speed F7000 --> F3000 (motor speed) - not realy necessary, but works better for my MK2
  • Renamed all "fpos_t" to "fpost" to avoid errors when compiling see http://forums.reprap.org/read.php?146,691608,724250#msg-724250)

comments.text: So I've been using this carriage for some time and I really like it except one design flaw.  The cable bundle support is too low and during the mesh probing it presses down on the heated bed connector cover.  I have an MK2s btw.  It will usually build the mesh but the back corner of the bed is unusable because it is thinking the bed is lower than it is at that point.  Also with the cable bundle that low on the carriage the bundle will sag enough to hit any tall prints on the back of the bed.  If it was pointing up at an angle and at least 10mm higher I think this would be the perfect carriage.  Is this something you could look into?  I'm going to try something on my own thank you for providing the STEP files.  Just wanted you to be aware. comments.text: Awesome design!!!  If I could suggest one thing.  For the Extruder mount hole (the plus shaped hole where the motor extrusion goes).  The hole is a really tight fit on my prusa motor, and does not allow for adjustment.  In my case, the axle of the motor is just a tiny bit too far from the gear, which results in a lot of clicks on retraction.  According to E3D this "is a result of the gears being able to move very slightly, independently of one and other".  Ideally, one would be able to move the motor a bit to account for this is, as is suggested in E3Ds instructions:  "The fix is simple, loosen the 3 screws that hold the body to the motor and rotate the extruder such that the gears are fully meshed. You know they are fully meshed when the large gear is no longer able to move freely. Re-tighten the screws on the lid and the problem should be fixed".  Unfortunately, with such a tight fit, this is impossible.  I have solved it by filing the rounded hole that accepts the motor extrusion to allow it to move slightly.  Adding 1 or 2 mm to the hole diameter would be perfect.
comments.author: chinooktx

comments.text: Indeed, you'll have to adjust the gear play for optimal performance and no "clicking". The hole is Ø22.1 as the motor has max. Ø22.0 or slightly smaller. If you've calibrated your printer properly, that should already allow for the necessary gear adjustment. At least for me it worked. I've enlared the hole to Ø22.3 in version V1.1 of the extruder mount. Anyway, it's no big deal to just grind the hole a little to allow for adjustment. Thanks for the input and let me know whether the adjustment is enough while also considering a proper printer calibration.
comments.author: chinooktx

customized with 3D Slash!

Clips for attaching a spring between 5mm diameter carbon push rods on Kossel printers. These help to take up the play in the rod end bearings, and also make the printer run a lot quieter. These were designed for the Anycubic Kossel Linear, but would suit others with 5mm rods.

If the rods are about 50mm apart, the distance between the holes for the spring would be 35mm. The springs I used were about 25mm length when relaxed, and came from this set:
"Rolson 61298 Spring Assortment - 150 Pieces" (http://amzn.eu/7vZyLfz)

I've also uploaded a "long" version which extends the clip length by 5mm (to suit wider rod spacing).

Update: I've now added an improved version 2 (long_v2) with the clip rotated to have more load bearing surface directly opposite to the spring (therefore less likely to pop off) and with slightly rounded edges for purely cosmetic reasons ;)

description.text:
This is my "First Layer Target". A 200 x 200 x 0.20 crosshair shaped target object which I use to test how good I levelled my print bet either manually or automatically. At the best setup it should print with exactly one layer at 100% layer height and have an even look everywhere on the bed!

I also included a 200 x 200 x 5 version which can be used to measure your x / y distortion across the whole printing area. This is much better than trying to do this on a 20x20x20 cube. Still I don't believe much into adjust steps as those are basically a constant for a given design. But that is another topic.

description.text:
Mashed up the frame of the YAFR and the screw adjusters of the marble machine rollers.

Also added printable hardware.

This stand works better when printed with all ABS or a mix of ABS and PLA, ABS has more grip and holds the screws in place well. PLA alone is too slick and the adjusting screws slip along the thread pin causing it to come out of adjustment easily when moving it.

Added a cutout version to save on filament.

comments.author: smoothdog001

comments.text: I print them on their sides for better adhesion and cleaner holes. It only takes a couple extra min to print the washers when I print the hardware set. Oh, I should give a shout out to the Nut Job customizer for making the assembly hardware job so easy! http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:193647
comments.author: MangoCats

comments.text: I started noticing after about a month that my prints weren't coming out as well as when the filament was new, bought a new spool and it was good for about a month before the same thing happened... that's why I started the dry-box project.  There's still some variation between colors and brands, but at least now there's not a variation over time.  The theory goes that humidity gets into the filament and does bad things.  The practice is that I start getting more shrinkage and bubbly surfaces, and the prints don't stick as easily to the build plate when the filament sits out in the open air.  Of course, we're in Florida, so humidity inside the house runs 60%+ most of the time - if you're in Colorado in the winter and you don't run humidifiers, your house air is dryer than the air inside my dry boxes.
comments.author: smoothdog001

Best regards,

title: Dungeon Dolls: Tome Wizard
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Updated 2/19/17

Ever like the variable designs of FlatMinis, but the customization of Dungeon Dolls? Ever wanted more options? Look no further! Inspired by the aesthetic of GrumpyRobot's FlatMinis, and DutchMogul's Dungeon Doll system, come Trixster_98's take on the classic Dungeon Doll.

This handy Wizard includes a book, staff made from a discarded stick, robe featuring a medallion, plain head, and a cape base if you wish or a plain base if not. I printed mine at 200% (Red) and the base stands at 56 mm tall. You can also print at 150% (Grey) which stands at 42 mm. Fully customizable and modular, look for more designs to come in the following weeks.

These designs are fully compatible with DutchMogul's original Dungeon Dolls, but not with FlatMinis
Made in Tinkercad, red printed at my library, grey printed on my Monoprice MP Select Mini
The remixed and improved version of my 2014 work that was unprintable and abandoned shortly after inception

Printing
The pieces should be printed at 150-200% depending on what you feel your printers accuracy to be. My printer can make all the details clearly visible at 100% but needs the print to be at 150% in order to fit together well.
The picture shows the 3 sizes of 200%, 150%, and 100%

Preparation
In order for the pieces to properly fit together, you will need to lightly sand them with a set of needle files. The heads just need very minute sanding in the eye holes. My first layer is always slightly off which always needs work in that one spot. The studs that attach to the shirt and pants need light sanding, but the holes should be fine, depending on your printers accuracy. The shirt stud typically needs a very small amount of sanding compared to the pant studs. The bottom that fits onto the base will most likely need sanding on both the hole and stud depending on accuracy.

Always test fit pieces together as you sand. I'm not responsible for ruined pieces due to too much sanding.

note
The handholes on the cloak will need quite a bit of sanding, but it's still pretty quick with good files. I'm working to correct this
